text: Hey Team,  is there a way to setup fake browsing data across test/example pages? (Will be showcasing the CMS off to some of the other dev teams on Monday). It'll be good to show off the Performance section of individual pages and the reports dashboards

We want to be able to use HubSpot for events, and that require that we can put a limit to the number of participants/submissions. Would be great to automate this process. lead signs up to event through a HubSpot form on a HubSpot landing page -> when the form have been submitted (for example) 50 times we want to make visitors see another form (for example “sign up here to get info about our upcoming events”. It’s this possible?
Let me ask around internally as I dont think there is a way to do the “after X submissions turn off form”

Hey Simon, currently there is no way to accomplish the “Turn off after X submissions” on forms. Have you checked out our App Marketplace for event integrators? <https://ecosystem.HubSpot.com/marketplace/apps/marketing/events> there may be something that can be done using an app like EventBrite
Is there a hubl tag that identifies a HubSpot Logged in user (not membership, actual HubSpot login)

from hs:
>Use of this variable will disable page caching.

No, because the cookies that identify users who are logged into the HubSpot app are set in <http://app.HubSpot.com|app.HubSpot.com>. If they were available on any customer domain, that would be a pretty big security hole!

A while back I was asking about the problem of not being able to create private files via the API for deals, when the same API seems to be used in the CRM’s UI.

IIRC, I was told something special happens somewhere along the way for files added via the UI. This is a frustrating limitation, but it seems like there are bigger, underlying security issues around the marketing file manager and CRM file attachments sharing the same code path.

For example, if you drag a file into a note on a deal, it’s routed to the marketing file manager and publicly available on the CDN. It’s hard to imagine a scenario where you’d want any file associated with a deal available to anyone who possesses (or discovers) the URL. There also might’ve been situations where this happened with files that our sales team attached via the Upload File button in the deal sidebar (HubSpot Support is looking into this, I can provide the ticket number if that’s helpful).

Anyhow, given the limitations it imposes on the integration side of things and the security risks it imposes on the user side of things, is this approach to handling files something your team is looking into changing?
ohhhh, just read the question more carefully… I guess my answer was of no use lol
if intentions got results, then I’d be a lot further in life :face_palm::skin-tone-2:

talk to me about any more cachebusting tricks. i have a set of templates that were originally built, not by me, with {{standard_footer_includes}} and a couple of script blocks outside the body tag.  Chrome rendered those pages with two body sections, of course, which resulted in a form being inserted not only where it was supposed to be, but also into that interpolated body section beneath the footer.

i’ve fixed all the templates, tested them in incognito windows, other browsers, and other laptops, and everything is perfect…. *except* in the original browser where i did the troubleshooting.

i’ve used the dev extension cachebuster…. repeatedly.
i’ve logged out and back in.
i’ve cleared the chrome cache and cookies via the Preferences panel, and via SingleClick Cleaner….. repeatedly.
i’ve verified i’m looking at the production page in every test, not any kind of preview page.
i’ve closed out of the browser to end sessions.
i’ve asked all my colleagues, who watch me do all of this over and over and are at a loss.

what more do i have to do? anyone?
